arXiv:2410.03919v1 [cs.LG] 04 Oct 2024

Online Posterior Sampling with a Diffusion Prior

Branislav Kveton
AWS AI Labs &Boris Oreshkin
Amazon &Youngsuk Park
AWS AI Labs &Aniket Deshmukh
AWS AI Labs &Rui Song
Amazon
Abstract

Posterior sampling in contextual bandits with a Gaussian prior can be implemented exactly or approximately using the Laplace approximation. The Gaussian prior is computationally efficient but it cannot describe complex distributions. In this work, we propose approximate posterior sampling algorithms for contextual bandits with a diffusion model prior. The key idea is to sample from a chain of approximate conditional posteriors, one for each stage of the reverse process, which are estimated in a closed form using the Laplace approximation. Our approximations are motivated by posterior sampling with a Gaussian prior, and inherit its simplicity and efficiency. They are asymptotically consistent and perform well empirically on a variety of contextual bandit problems.

1 Introduction

A multi-armed bandit [26, 6, 29] is an online learning problem where an agent sequentially interacts with an environment over nùëõnitalic_n rounds with the goal of maximizing its rewards. In each round, it takes an action and receives its stochastic reward. The mean rewards of the actions are unknown a priori and must be learned. This leads to the exploration-exploitation dilemma: explore actions to learn about them or exploit the action with the highest estimated reward. Bandits have been successfully applied to problems where uncertainty modeling and adaptation to it are beneficial, such as in recommender systems [31, 53, 24, 34] and hyper-parameter optimization [33].

Contextual bandits [28, 31] with linear [13, 1] and generalized linear models (GLMs) [16, 32, 2, 25] have become popular due to the their flexibility and efficiency. The features in these models can be hand-crafted or learned from historic data [39], and the models can be also updated incrementally [1, 23]. While the original algorithms for linear and GLM bandits were based on upper confidence bounds (UCBs) [13, 1, 16], Thompson sampling (TS) is more popular in practice [11, 3, 41, 43]. The key idea in TS is to explore by sampling from the posterior distribution of model parameter Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. TS uses the prior knowledge about Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to speed up exploration [11, 39, 35, 9, 20, 19, 5]. When the prior is a multivariate Gaussian, the posterior of Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be updated and sampled from efficiently [11]. Unfortunately, this prior has limited expressive power, because it cannot even represent multimodal distributions. To address this limitation, we study posterior sampling with complex priors.

We make the following contributions. First, we propose novel posterior sampling approximations for linear models and GLMs with a diffusion model prior. The key idea is to sample from a chain of approximate conditional posteriors, one for each stage of the reverse process, which are estimated in a closed form. In linear models, each conditional is a product of two Gaussians, representing prior knowledge and diffused evidence (Theorem 2). In GLMs, each conditional is obtained by a Laplace approximation, which mixes prior knowledge and evidence (Theorem 4). Our approximations are motivated by posterior sampling with a Gaussian prior, and inherit its simplicity and efficiency. The prior works (Section 7) rely on the score of the likelihood of observations. In online learning, the likelihood score tends to infinity as the number of observations increases, which causes divergence of the existing approximations (Section 6.2).

Our second major contribution is in theory. More specifically, we prove that our posterior approximation is asymptotically consistent (Theorem 3). The key idea in the proof is that the conditional posteriors in Theorem 2 concentrate at a scaled unknown model parameter as the number of observations increases. While this claim is asymptotic, it is an expected property of a posterior distribution. Many prior works, such as Chung et al. [12], do not poses this property.

Our last contribution is empirical evaluation on contextual bandit problems. We focus on bandits because the ability to represent all levels of uncertainty well is critical for exploration. Our experiments (Section 6.2) show that a score-based method fails to do so. Note that our posterior approximations are general and not restricted to bandits.

2.2 Generalized Linear Model

Generalized linear models (GLMs) [36] extend linear models (Section 2.1) to non-linear monotone mean functions gùëîgitalic_g in (1). For instance, in logistic regression, g‚Å¢(u)=1/(1+exp‚Å°[‚àíu])ùëîùë¢11ùë¢g(u)=1/(1+\exp[-u])italic_g ( italic_u ) = 1 / ( 1 + roman_exp [ - italic_u ] ) is a sigmoid. The likelihood of observations in GLMs has the following form [25].

Assumption 2.

2.3 Towards Diffusion Model Priors

The assumption that p‚Å¢(Œ∏‚àó)=ùí©‚Å¢(Œ∏‚àó;Œ∏0,Œ£0)ùëùsubscriptùúÉùí©subscriptùúÉsubscriptùúÉ0subscriptŒ£0p(\theta_{*})=\mathcal{N}(\theta_{*};\theta_{0},\Sigma_{0})italic_p ( italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is limiting, for instance because it precludes multimodal priors. We relax it by representing p‚Å¢(Œ∏‚àó)ùëùsubscriptùúÉp(\theta_{*})italic_p ( italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by a diffusion model, which we call a diffusion model prior. We propose an efficient posterior sampling approximation for this prior where the prior and empirical evidence are mixed similarly to (3) and ùô∏ùöÅùôªùöÇùô∏ùöÅùôªùöÇ\tt IRLStypewriter_IRLS (Section 4). Before we do this, we review diffusion models in Section 3.

3 Diffusion Models

A diffusion model [45, 18] is a generative model trained by diffusing samples from an unknown distribution. While multiple types of diffusion models exist [48], we adopt the probabilistic formulation and presentation of Ho et al. [18]. A diffusion model is a graphical model with TùëáTitalic_T stages indexed by t‚àà[T]ùë°delimited-[]ùëát\in[T]italic_t ‚àà [ italic_T ]. Each stage tùë°titalic_t is associated with a latent variable St‚àà‚ÑùdsubscriptùëÜùë°superscript‚ÑùùëëS_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A sample from the model is represented by an observed variable S0‚àà‚ÑùdsubscriptùëÜ0superscript‚ÑùùëëS_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We visualize the diffusion model in Figure 1. In the forward process, the sample s0subscriptùë†0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is diffused through a sequence of variables S1,‚Ä¶,STsubscriptùëÜ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜùëáS_{1},\dots,S_{T}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This process is used to learn the reverse process, where the sample s0subscriptùë†0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated through a sequence of variables ST,‚Ä¶,S0subscriptùëÜùëá‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜ0S_{T},\dots,S_{0}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To sample s0subscriptùë†0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the posterior (Section 4), we add a random variable HùêªHitalic_H, which represents partial information about s0subscriptùë†0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We introduce forward and reverse diffusion processes next. Learning of the reverse process is described in Appendix B. While this is a critical component of diffusion models, it is not necessary to introduce our posterior approximations.

4 Posterior Sampling

This section is organized as follows. We derive a general posterior distribution for a chain of random variables conditioned on observations in Section 4.1. After that, in Sections 4.2 and 4.4, we specialize it to the observation models in Section 2.

4.1 Chain Model Posterior

The algorithm that samples from the posterior distribution in Theorem 2 is presented in Algorithm 2. When compared to Section 2, the prior and empirical evidence are mixed conditionally in a TùëáTitalic_T-stage chain. We validate this empirically in Section 6.2.

4.3 Key Approximation in Theorem 2

Now we motivate our approximation in (6). Our approximation has several notable properties. First, (1‚àíŒ±¬Øt)/Œ±¬Øt‚Üí0‚Üí1subscript¬Øùõºùë°subscript¬Øùõºùë°0\sqrt{(1-\bar{\alpha}_{t})/\bar{\alpha}_{t}}\to 0square-root start_ARG ( 1 - over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ‚Üí 0 as t‚Üí1‚Üíùë°1t\to 1italic_t ‚Üí 1. Therefore, it becomes more precise in later stages of the reverse process. Second, in the absence of evidence h‚Ñéhitalic_h, the approximation vanishes, and all posterior distributions in Theorem 2 reduce to the priors in (5). Finally, as the number of observations increases, sampling from the posterior in Theorem 2 is asymptotically consistent.

The bound in Theorem 3 can be interpreted as follows. The sampled parameter Œ∏~~ùúÉ\tilde{\theta}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∏ end_ARG approaches the true unknown parameter Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the number of observations NùëÅNitalic_N increases. To guarantee that the posterior shrinks uniformly in all directions, we assume that the number of observations in all directions grows linearly with NùëÅNitalic_N. This lower bound can be attained in linear models by choosing feature vectors according to the D-optimal design [38]. Since our proof is asymptotic, we can neglect some finite-time errors and this simplifies the argument.

4.4 GLM Posterior

The Laplace approximation in GLMs (Section 2.2) naturally generalizes the exact posterior distribution in linear models (Section 2.1). We generalize Theorem 2 to GLMs along the same lines.

Similarly to Theorem 2, the distributions in Theorem 4 mix evidence with the diffusion model prior. However, this is done implicitly in ùô∏ùöÅùôªùöÇùô∏ùöÅùôªùöÇ\tt IRLStypewriter_IRLS. Note that Theorem 2 is a special case of Theorem 4 where the mean function gùëîgitalic_g is an identity.

5 Application to Contextual Bandits

Now we apply our posterior sampling approximations (Section 4) to contextual bandits. A contextual bandit [28, 31] is a classic model for sequential decision making under uncertainty where the agent takes actions conditioned on context. We denote the action set by ùíúùíú\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and the context set by ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. The mean reward of action a‚ààùíúùëéùíúa\in\mathcal{A}italic_a ‚àà caligraphic_A in context x‚ààùí≥ùë•ùí≥x\in\mathcal{X}italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_X is r‚Å¢(x,a;Œ∏‚àó)ùëüùë•ùëésubscriptùúÉr(x,a;\theta_{*})italic_r ( italic_x , italic_a ; italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where r:ùí≥√óùíú√óŒò‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëü‚Üíùí≥ùíúŒò‚Ñùr:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\times\Theta\to\mathbb{R}italic_r : caligraphic_X √ó caligraphic_A √ó roman_Œò ‚Üí blackboard_R is some reward function and Œ∏‚àó‚ààŒòsubscriptùúÉŒò\theta_{*}\in\Thetaitalic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà roman_Œò is an unknown model parameter (Section 2). The agent interacts with the bandit for nùëõnitalic_n rounds indexed by k‚àà[n]ùëòdelimited-[]ùëõk\in[n]italic_k ‚àà [ italic_n ]. In round kùëòkitalic_k, the agent observes a context xk‚ààùí≥subscriptùë•ùëòùí≥x_{k}\in\mathcal{X}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_X, takes an action ak‚ààùíúsubscriptùëéùëòùíúa_{k}\in\mathcal{A}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_A, and observes a stochastic reward yk=r‚Å¢(xk,ak;Œ∏‚àó)+Œµksubscriptùë¶ùëòùëüsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùúÉsubscriptùúÄùëòy_{k}=r(x_{k},a_{k};\theta_{*})+\varepsilon_{k}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ŒµksubscriptùúÄùëò\varepsilon_{k}italic_Œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent zero-mean œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-sub-Gaussian noise for œÉ>0ùúé0\sigma>0italic_œÉ > 0. The goal of the agent is to maximize its cumulative reward in nùëõnitalic_n rounds, or equivalently to minimize its cumulative regret. We define the nùëõnitalic_n-round regret as R‚Å¢(n)=‚àëk=1nùîº‚Å¢[r‚Å¢(xk,ak,‚àó;Œ∏‚àó)‚àír‚Å¢(xk,ak;Œ∏‚àó)]ùëÖùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëõùîºdelimited-[]ùëüsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùúÉùëüsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëéùëòsubscriptùúÉR(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}\left[r(x_{k},a_{k,*};\theta_{*})-r(x_{k},a_{k};% \theta_{*})\right]italic_R ( italic_n ) = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_r ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_r ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ], where ak,‚àósubscriptùëéùëòa_{k,*}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the optimal action in round kùëòkitalic_k.

Arguably the most popular approach to solving contextual bandit problems is Thompson sampling [49, 11, 3]. The key idea in TS is to use the posterior distribution of Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to explore. This is done as follows. After that, the agent takes the action with the highest mean reward under Œ∏~ksubscript~ùúÉùëò\tilde{\theta}_{k}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The pseudo-code of this algorithm is given in Algorithm 3.

A generalized linear bandit [16, 23, 32, 25] is an extension of linear bandits to generalized linear models (Section 2.2). When the prior distribution is a diffusion model, we propose sampling from (9), where Œº^tsubscript^ùúáùë°\hat{\mu}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ£^tsubscript^Œ£ùë°\hat{\Sigma}_{t}over^ start_ARG roman_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in ùôªùöäùöôùöïùöäùöåùöéùô≥ùôøùöÇùôªùöäùöôùöïùöäùöåùöéùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt LaplaceDPStypewriter_LaplaceDPS are set according to Theorem 4.

6 Experiments

We conduct three experiments: synthetic problems in 2222 dimensions (Sections 6.2 and C.1), a recommender system (Section 6.3), and a classification problem (Section C.2). In addition, we conduct an ablation study in Section C.3, where we vary the number of training samples for the diffusion prior and the number of diffusion stages TùëáTitalic_T.

6.1 Experimental Setup

We have four baselines. Three baselines are variants of contextual Thompson sampling [11, 3]: with an uninformative Gaussian prior (ùöÉùöÇùöÉùöÇ\tt TStypewriter_TS), a learned Gaussian prior (ùöÉùöûùöóùöéùöçùöÉùöÇùöÉùöûùöóùöéùöçùöÉùöÇ\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS), and a learned Gaussian mixture prior (ùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇ\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS) [21]. The last baseline is diffusion posterior sampling (ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS) of Chung et al. [12]. We implement all TS baselines as described in Section 5. The uninformative prior is ùí©‚Å¢(ùüéd,Id)ùí©subscript0ùëësubscriptùêºùëë\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}_{d},I_{d})caligraphic_N ( bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). ùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇ\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS is used only in linear bandit experiments because the logistic regression variant does not exist. The TS baselines are chosen to cover various levels of prior information. Our implementation of ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS is described in Appendix D. We also experimented with frequentist baselines, such as ùôªùöíùöóùöÑùô≤ùô±ùôªùöíùöóùöÑùô≤ùô±\tt LinUCBtypewriter_LinUCB [1] and the ŒµùúÄ\varepsilonitalic_Œµ-greedy policy. They performed worse than ùöÉùöÇùöÉùöÇ\tt TStypewriter_TS and thus we do not report them here.

Each experiment is set up as follows. First, the prior distribution of Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is specified: it can be synthetic or estimated from real-world data. Second, we learn this distribution from 10‚Äâ0001000010\,00010 000 samples from it. In ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS and ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS, we follow Appendix B. The number of stages is T=100ùëá100T=100italic_T = 100 and the diffusion factor is Œ±t=0.97subscriptùõºùë°0.97\alpha_{t}=0.97italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.97. Since 0.97100‚âà0.05superscript0.971000.050.97^{100}\approx 0.050.97 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚âà 0.05, most of the information in the training samples is diffused. The regressor in Appendix B is a 2222-layer neural network with ReLU activations. In ùöÉùöûùöóùöéùöçùöÉùöÇùöÉùöûùöóùöéùöçùöÉùöÇ\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS, we fit the mean and covariance using maximum likelihood estimation. In ùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇ\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS, we fit the Gaussian mixture using scikit-learn. All algorithms are evaluated on Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sampled from the true prior.

6.2 Synthetic Experiment

The first experiment is on three synthetic problems. Each problem is a linear bandit (Section 5) with K=100ùêæ100K=100italic_K = 100 actions in d=2ùëë2d=2italic_d = 2 dimensions. The reward noise is œÉ=2ùúé2\sigma=2italic_œÉ = 2. The feature vectors of actions are sampled uniformly at random from a unit ball. The prior distributions of Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in Figure 2. The first is a mixture of two Gaussians and the last can be approximated well by a mixture of two Gaussians. ùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇ\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS is implemented with two mixture components, which can exactly represent the first prior and approximate the last one well.

Our results are reported in Figure 2. We observe two main trends. First, samples from the diffusion prior closely resemble those from the true prior. In such cases, ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS is expected to perform well and even outperforms ùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇ\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS, because it has a better representation of the prior. We observe this in all problems. Second, ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS diverges as the number of rounds increases. This is because ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS relies on the score of the likelihood of observations (Section 7), which tends to infinity as the number of observations increases. This happens despite tuning (Appendix D). We report results on additional synthetic problems in Section C.1.

ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS should be TùëáTitalic_T times more computationally costly than ùöÉùöÇùöÉùöÇ\tt TStypewriter_TS with a Gaussian prior (Section 4.2). We observe this empirically. As an example, the average cost of 100100100100 runs of ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS on any problem in Figure 2 is 12121212 seconds. The average cost of ùöÉùöÇùöÉùöÇ\tt TStypewriter_TS is 0.10.10.10.1 seconds. The computation and accuracy can be traded off, and we investigate this in Section C.3. In Problem \saycross, we vary the number of diffusion stages from T=1ùëá1T=1italic_T = 1 to T=300ùëá300T=300italic_T = 300. We observe that the computational cost is linear in TùëáTitalic_T and the regret drops quickly from around 85858585 at T=1ùëá1T=1italic_T = 1 to 50505050 at T=25ùëá25T=25italic_T = 25.

6.3 MovieLens Experiment

In the second experiment, we learn to recommend an item to randomly arriving users. The problem is simulated using the MovieLens 1M dataset [27], with 1111 million ratings for 3‚Äâ70637063\,7063 706 movies from 6‚Äâ04060406\,0406 040 users. As a first step, we subtract the mean rating from all ratings and complete the sparse rating matrix MùëÄMitalic_M by alternating least squares [14] with rank d=5ùëë5d=5italic_d = 5. The learned factorization is M=U‚Å¢V‚ä§ùëÄùëàsuperscriptùëâtopM=UV^{\top}italic_M = italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The iùëñiitalic_i-th row of UùëàUitalic_U, denoted by UisubscriptùëàùëñU_{i}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, represents user iùëñiitalic_i. The jùëójitalic_j-th row of VùëâVitalic_V, denoted by VjsubscriptùëâùëóV_{j}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, represents movie jùëójitalic_j. We use the item embeddings VjsubscriptùëâùëóV_{j}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as unknown model parameters and the user embeddings UisubscriptùëàùëñU_{i}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as features of the actions.

We experiment with both linear and logistic bandits. In both, an item is initially chosen randomly from VjsubscriptùëâùëóV_{j}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K=10ùêæ10K=10italic_K = 10 random actions are chosen from UisubscriptùëàùëñU_{i}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in each round. In the linear bandit, the mean reward for recommending item jùëójitalic_j to user iùëñiitalic_i is Ui‚ä§‚Å¢VjsuperscriptsubscriptùëàùëñtopsubscriptùëâùëóU_{i}^{\top}V_{j}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The reward noise is œÉ=0.75ùúé0.75\sigma=0.75italic_œÉ = 0.75 and estimated from data. In the logistic bandit, the mean reward is g‚Å¢(Ui‚ä§‚Å¢Vj)ùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùëàùëñtopsubscriptùëâùëóg(U_{i}^{\top}V_{j})italic_g ( italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where gùëîgitalic_g is a sigmoid.

Our MovieLens results are shown in Figure 3. We observe the same trends as in Section 6.2. First, samples from the diffusion prior closely resemble those from the true prior (Figure 3a). Since the problem is higher dimensional, we visualize the overlap using a UMAP projection [44]. Second, ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS has a significantly lower regret than all baselines, in both linear (Figure 3b) and logistic (Figure 3c) bandits. Finally, ùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇùôºùöíùö°ùöÉùöÇ\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS barely outperforms ùöÉùöûùöóùöéùöçùöÉùöÇùöÉùöûùöóùöéùöçùöÉùöÇ\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS. We observe this trend consistently in higher dimensions, which motivated our work on online learning with more complex priors.

7 Related Work

There are two lines of related works: bandits with diffusion models and posterior sampling in diffusion models. We start with the former. Hsieh et al. [22] proposed Thompson sampling with a diffusion model prior for KùêæKitalic_K-armed bandits. We consider a more general setting of contextual bandits and also develop new posterior sampling approximations for it. Aouali [4] proposed and analyzed contextual bandits with a linear diffusion model prior: Œºt‚Å¢(st)subscriptùúáùë°subscriptùë†ùë°\mu_{t}(s_{t})italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (5) is linear in stsubscriptùë†ùë°s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and q‚Å¢(s0)ùëûsubscriptùë†0q(s_{0})italic_q ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Gaussian. Due to this assumption, the resulting model is just a linear Gaussian model and not a general diffusion model, as in our work.

The closest related work on posterior sampling in diffusion models is ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS of Chung et al. [12]. The key idea in ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS is to sample from a diffusion model posterior by adding the score of the likelihood of observations to it. In our notation, this is ‚àálog‚Å°p‚Å¢(h‚à£Œ∏)‚àáùëùconditional‚ÑéùúÉ\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)‚àá roman_log italic_p ( italic_h ‚à£ italic_Œ∏ ), where p‚Å¢(h‚à£Œ∏)ùëùconditional‚ÑéùúÉp(h\mid\theta)italic_p ( italic_h ‚à£ italic_Œ∏ ) is defined in Assumptions 1 and 2. Note that ‚àálog‚Å°p‚Å¢(h‚à£Œ∏)‚àáùëùconditional‚ÑéùúÉ\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)‚àá roman_log italic_p ( italic_h ‚à£ italic_Œ∏ ) grows linearly in NùëÅNitalic_N. Therefore, ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS becomes unstable as N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\inftyitalic_N ‚Üí ‚àû. See our empirical results in Section 6.2 and the implementation of ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS in Appendix D, which was tuned to improve its stability. Other methods for posterior sampling in diffusion models have been proposed recently: a sequential Monte Carlo approximation for the conditional reverse process [52], a variant of ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS with an uninformative prior [37], a pseudo-inverse approximation to the likelihood of evidence [47], and posterior sampling in latent diffusion models [40]. All of these methods rely on the score of the likelihood ‚àálog‚Å°p‚Å¢(h‚à£Œ∏)‚àáùëùconditional‚ÑéùúÉ\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)‚àá roman_log italic_p ( italic_h ‚à£ italic_Œ∏ ) and thus become unstable as the number of observations NùëÅNitalic_N increases. Our posterior approximations do not have this issue because they are based on the product of prior and evidence distributions (Theorems 2 and 4), and thus gradient-free. They work well across different levels of uncertainty (Section 6) and do not require tuning.

We also wanted to note that posterior sampling is a special from of guiding generation in diffusion models. Other approaches include conditional pre-training [15], a constraint in the reverse process [17], refining the null-space content [50], solving an optimization problem that pushes the reverse process towards evidence [46], and aligning the reverse process with the prompt [7].

8 Conclusions

We propose posterior sampling approximations for diffusion models priors. These approximations are contextual, and can be implemented efficiently in linear models and GLMs. We analyze them and evaluate them empirically on contextual bandit problems.

Our work focuses on developing novel posterior approximations rather than a regret analysis. This is because the existing approximations are unstable and may diverge in the online setting (Sections 7 and 6.2). A proper regret bound for ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS would require analyzing two errors. The first error arises because the reverse process reverses the forward process only approximately (Appendix B). The second error arises because our posteriors are only approximate (Section 4.3). That being said, prior works already provided general insights on the utility of complex priors. For instance, Russo and Van Roy [42] proved a O‚Å¢(Œì‚Å¢H‚Å¢(A‚àó)‚Å¢n)ùëÇŒìùêªsubscriptùê¥ùëõO(\sqrt{\Gamma H(A_{*})n})italic_O ( square-root start_ARG roman_Œì italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_n end_ARG ) regret bound for a linear bandit, where ŒìŒì\Gammaroman_Œì is the maximum ratio of regret to information gain and H‚Å¢(A‚àó)ùêªsubscriptùê¥H(A_{*})italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the entropy of the distribution of the optimal action under the prior. In short, the bound says that a lower entropy H‚Å¢(A‚àó)ùêªsubscriptùê¥H(A_{*})italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which reflects how concentrated the prior is, yields a lower regret.

Finally, we believe that our ideas can be extended beyond GLMs. The key idea in Section 4.4 is to use the Laplace approximation of the likelihood. This approximation can be computed exactly in GLMs. More generally though, it is a good approximation whenever the likelihood can be approximated well by a single Gaussian distribution. By the central limit theorem, under appropriate conditions, this is expected for any observation model when the number of observations is large.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

This section contains three additional experiments.

C.1 Additional Synthetic Problems

In Section 6.2, we show results for three hand-selected problems out of six. We report results on the other three problems in Figure 4. We observe the same trends as in Section 6.2. The only minor change is that ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS does not diverge on the last problem.

C.2 MNIST Experiment

The next experiment is on the MNIST dataset [30], where the mean reward is estimated by a classifier. We start with learning an MLP-based multi-way classifier for digits and extract d=8ùëë8d=8italic_d = 8 dimensional embeddings of all digits in the dataset, which are used as feature vectors in our experiment. We generate a distribution over model parameters Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows: (1) we choose a random positive label, assign it reward 1111, and assign reward ‚àí11-1- 1 to all other labels; (2) we subsample a random dataset of size 20202020, with 50%percent5050\%50 % positive and 50%percent5050\%50 % negative labels; (3) we train a linear model, which gives us a single Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We repeat this 10‚Äâ0001000010\,00010 000 times and get a distribution over Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We consider both linear and logistic bandits. In both, the model parameter Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is initially sampled from the prior. In each round, K=10ùêæ10K=10italic_K = 10 random actions are chosen randomly from all digits. In the linear bandit, the mean reward for digit xùë•xitalic_x is x‚ä§‚Å¢Œ∏‚àósuperscriptùë•topsubscriptùúÉx^{\top}\theta_{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the reward noise is œÉ=1ùúé1\sigma=1italic_œÉ = 1. In the logistic bandit, the mean reward is g‚Å¢(x‚ä§‚Å¢Œ∏‚àó)ùëîsuperscriptùë•topsubscriptùúÉg(x^{\top}\theta_{*})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where gùëîgitalic_g is a sigmoid.

Our MNIST results are reported in Figure 5. We observe again that ùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇùô≥ùöíùöèùöèùöÉùöÇ\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS has a lower regret than all baselines, because the learned prior captures the underlying distribution of Œ∏‚àósubscriptùúÉ\theta_{*}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUBSCRIPT well. We note that both the prior and diffusion prior distributions exhibit a strong cluster structure (Figure 5a), where each cluster represents one label.

C.3 Ablation Studies

We conduct three ablation studies on the cross problem in Figure 2.

In all experiments, the number of samples for training diffusion priors was 10‚Äâ0001000010\,00010 000. In Figure 6a, we vary it from 100100100100 to 10‚Äâ0001000010\,00010 000. We observe that the regret decreases as the number of samples increases, due to learning a more accurate prior approximation. It stabilizes around 3‚Äâ00030003\,0003 000 training samples. We conclude that the quality of the learned prior approximation has a major impact on regret.

In all experiments, the number of diffusion stages was T=100ùëá100T=100italic_T = 100. In Figure 6b, we vary it from 1111 to 300300300300 and observe its impact on regret. The regret at T=1ùëá1T=1italic_T = 1 is high, but then it drops quickly up to T=25ùëá25T=25italic_T = 25. It stabilizes around T=100ùëá100T=100italic_T = 100, which we used in our experiments. In Figure 6c, we vary TùëáTitalic_T from 1111 to 300300300300 and observe its impact on the computation time of posterior sampling. As suggested in Section 4.2, it increases linearly with TùëáTitalic_T. The main contribution to the computation time are TùëáTitalic_T calls to the neural network regressor.

While this significantly improves the performance of ùô≥ùôøùöÇùô≥ùôøùöÇ\tt DPStypewriter_DPS, it does not prevent failures. The fundamental problem is that gradient-based optimization is sensitive to the step size, especially when the optimized function is steep. We do not have any such hyper-parameter in our algorithm.
